title: How to Make Lye Soap from Biodiesel By products

steps.headline: Place the glycerin in a stainless steel pot and heat it to 150 °F (66 °C) to remove any traces of methanol.
steps.description: Heat it to 175 °F (79 °C) if you made your biodiesel from ethanol.

steps.headline: Strain the glycerin to remove any impurities and then return it to the pot.
Measure 1 qt.
steps.description: of water for every gallon of glycerin and heat the water to 100 °F (38 °C). This works out to a 1-to-4 ratio of water to glycerin.

steps.headline: Stir approximately 5.5 oz.
steps.description: of lye (38.5 grams per liter) into the heated water until it is completely dissolved.

steps.headline: Add the water and lye mixture to the glycerin.
Continue to heat for another 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Remove the mixture from the heat and stir for another 10 minutes.
steps.description: You may see it start to foam.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into a shallow container.
steps.description: A plastic storage bin with a lid works well. The size and number of containers needed depends on the amount of glycerin you are using and the desired thickness of the soap. For 1 ½ gallons of glycerin, use a 28-qt. container to make 1 ½-inch-thick soap.

steps.headline: Cover the liquid with a piece of plywood or cardboard to help hold the heat in so the soap cures properly.
steps.description: Let it cool and solidify for 24 hours.

steps.headline: Run a knife around the edge of the soap to loosen it and then flip the container over to remove the soap.

Wait at least 4 more days before using the soap.
steps.description: During this additional drying time, the soap will turn from a dark brown to a lighter tan color.

steps.headline: Store the soap in zipper plastic bags with wax paper between the bars so they don’t stick together.

text: Place the glycerin in a stainless steel pot and heat it to 150 °F (66 °C) to remove any traces of methanol. Heat it to 175 °F (79 °C) if you made your biodiesel from ethanol. Strain the glycerin to remove any impurities and then return it to the pot.  Measure 1 qt. of water for every gallon of glycerin and heat the water to 100 °F (38 °C). This works out to a 1-to-4 ratio of water to glycerin. Stir approximately 5.5 oz. of lye (38.5 grams per liter) into the heated water until it is completely dissolved. Add the water and lye mixture to the glycerin.  Continue to heat for another 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.  Remove the mixture from the heat and stir for another 10 minutes. You may see it start to foam. Pour the mixture into a shallow container. A plastic storage bin with a lid works well. The size and number of containers needed depends on the amount of glycerin you are using and the desired thickness of the soap. For 1 ½ gallons of glycerin, use a 28-qt. container to make 1 ½-inch-thick soap. Cover the liquid with a piece of plywood or cardboard to help hold the heat in so the soap cures properly. Let it cool and solidify for 24 hours. Run a knife around the edge of the soap to loosen it and then flip the container over to remove the soap.  Cut the soap into 45 bars that measure 3-by-2 inches (5.1 cm).  Wait at least 4 more days before using the soap. During this additional drying time, the soap will turn from a dark brown to a lighter tan color. Store the soap in zipper plastic bags with wax paper between the bars so they don’t stick together.
